column4: how would I create a file so that it is "binary" and coudn't be read with gedit?
put some rubbish there
tried that, it just opens up the rubbish
ah, do you want geany to produce an error while trying to open the file, or what?
I want it to give me that "Encoding not found" error.
no idea. just put some /dev/urandom there!
that worked! and it still hides the message I added with bless! It also happens to be 89MB, but I can fix that later
But generally, you want something strange, imo.
Also, it depends on the kind of key you are generating
its an RSA key
RSA keys should be a bit longer, but 4096 still should be enough
my key is 16384 bits, i'm guessing thats enough
You're going to gain a lot of time to drink tea, I believe, without much enchancing your security. "enough" means, that nowadays people'd need 100 or so years to decrypt it.
it only took about 10 mins to make the key, will it have an effect on how long it takes to ssh to the machine?
It shouldn't.
if I wanted to make a key that was twice as big, would it take twice as long, the square as long, or somewhere in between?
Well, it should work like this, but you're looking in a wrong place to enchance your security.
well, I probably won't really use this key much, I just wanted to know how much I could do. Hopefully someone doesn't make a working quantum computer soon.
If he makes, then even 100K bit key won't help. Thus, let's take it easy! :)
well, this is just a theory of mine, but I bet that if you can break current keys easily with a quantum computer, i'm betting that you can easily create massive keys too.
No, unfortunately, it doesn't work like this. However, there *are* completely new ways to protect information, just google for quantum criptography, and prepare for a complete brain corruption! :-]
ASULutzy: yeah, I probably know way to much about quantum stuff for my age (13). Time to end this conversation before we get !ot ed.
